body: You need to _build_ on those systems?

Just to be sure, the problem is that RHEL 5 itself does not include XInput2 in its distribution.  It is not simply a matter of a particular system missing the appropriate package.

Perhaps I don't absolutely need to build on these systems, but in general I've found that building binaries and transporting them across major OS versions, or between individual systems, to be problematic, especially trying to run code on an older OS (RHEL 5), that was built on a newer OS (RHEL 6).

As far as I'm aware, it is common practice in the HPC world to compile binaries for specific systems, or at least only transport binaries across very similar systems and OS versions.   One example of a problem I've faced with this issue, is that on one of the visualization clusters I run my code on, I can compile on either the login or visualization nodes, both of which are Redhat 6, but due to slight differences in the system configuration, a binary built on the login node will not run on the visualization node.

I guess I could try compiling on RHEL 6 and then running that binary on RHEL 5, but that's just asking for trouble in other areas, in which case I'd rather just use SDL2.  I was hoping that it might be a relatively minor matter of detecting XInput2.h in CMake and disabling some code in GLFW, but perhaps it's not too simple and I'm the only GLFW user still having to deal with RHEL 5. So if this is too much work with too little payoff, then nevermind :)

Same situation here, aiming to support CentOS 5 as baseline for RedHat/Fedora/CentOS.
- Nigel
Thank you!  I really appreciate it.
I suspect I won't like the answer but what's the CMake version on those ancient systems?

To answer your question directly, for the latest point releases, CentOS 5 has 2.6.4 [1], CentOS 6 has 2.8.12 [2].  I was under the impression that earlier version of CentOS 6 had a significantly older CMake, since that's actually newer than what's included in CentOS 7.

I appreciate greatly your consideration of those of us required to support these legacy systems, however, upgrading cmake in user-space is not a big deal, my two cents would be to just worry about maintaining compatibility with more fundamental system components like X11, and to just do what is most convenient for you in terms of the build system.

[1] http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/x86_64/CentOS/
[2] http://mirror.centos.org/centos/6/os/x86_64/Packages/
